lines.text: Enter VIOLA, and Clown with a tabour

lines.speaker: viola
lines.text: Save thee, friend, and thy music: dost thou live by thy tabour?

lines.speaker: clown
lines.text: No, sir, I live by the church.

lines.speaker: viola
lines.text: Art thou a churchman?

lines.speaker: clown
lines.text: No such matter, sir: I do live by the church; for I do live at my house, and my house doth stand by the church.

lines.speaker: viola
lines.text: So thou mayst say, the king lies by a beggar, if a beggar dwell near him; or, the church stands by thy tabour, if thy tabour stand by the church.

lines.speaker: clown
lines.text: You have said, sir. To see this age! A sentence is but a cheveril glove to a good wit: how quickly the wrong side may be turned outward!

lines.speaker: viola
lines.text: Nay, that's certain; they that dally nicely with words may quickly make them wanton.

lines.speaker: clown
lines.text: I would, therefore, my sister had had no name, sir.

lines.speaker: viola
lines.text: Why, man?

lines.speaker: clown
lines.text: Why, sir, her name's a word; and to dally with that word might make my sister wanton. But indeed words are very rascals since bonds disgraced them.

lines.speaker: viola
lines.text: Thy reason, man?

lines.speaker: clown
lines.text: Troth, sir, I can yield you none without words; and words are grown so false, I am loath to prove reason with them.

lines.speaker: viola
lines.text: I warrant thou art a merry fellow and carest for nothing.

lines.speaker: clown
lines.text: Not so, sir, I do care for something; but in my conscience, sir, I do not care for you: if that be to care for nothing, sir, I would it would make you invisible.

lines.speaker: viola
lines.text: Art not thou the Lady Olivia's fool?

lines.speaker: clown
lines.text: No, indeed, sir; the Lady Olivia has no folly: she will keep no fool, sir, till she be married; and fools are as like husbands as pilchards are to herrings; the husband's the bigger: I am indeed not her fool, but her corrupter of words.

lines.speaker: viola
lines.text: I saw thee late at the Count Orsino's.

lines.speaker: clown
lines.text: Foolery, sir, does walk about the orb like the sun, it shines every where. I would be sorry, sir, but the fool should be as oft with your master as with my mistress: I think I saw your wisdom there.

lines.speaker: viola
lines.text: Nay, an thou pass upon me, I'll no more with thee. Hold, there's expenses for thee.

lines.speaker: clown
lines.text: Now Jove, in his next commodity of hair, send thee a beard!

lines.speaker: viola
lines.text: By my troth, I'll tell thee, I am almost sick for one; though I would not have it grow on my chin. Is thy lady within?
Aside

lines.speaker: clown
lines.text: Would not a pair of these have bred, sir?

lines.speaker: viola
lines.text: Yes, being kept together and put to use.

lines.speaker: clown
lines.text: I would play Lord Pandarus of Phrygia, sir, to bring a Cressida to this Troilus.

lines.speaker: viola
lines.text: I understand you, sir; 'tis well begged.

lines.speaker: clown
lines.text: The matter, I hope, is not great, sir, begging but a beggar: Cressida was a beggar. My lady is within, sir. I will construe to them whence you come; who you are and what you would are out of my welkin, I might say 'element,' but the word is over-worn.
Exit

lines.speaker: viola
lines.text: This fellow is wise enough to play the fool; And to do that well craves a kind of wit: He must observe their mood on whom he jests, The quality of persons, and the time, And, like the haggard, cheque at every feather That comes before his eye. This is a practise As full of labour as a wise man's art For folly that he wisely shows is fit; But wise men, folly-fall'n, quite taint their wit.
Enter SIR TOBY BELCH, and SIR ANDREW

lines.speaker: sir toby belch
lines.text: Save you, gentleman.

lines.speaker: viola
lines.text: And you, sir.

lines.speaker: sir andrew
lines.text: Dieu vous garde, monsieur.

lines.speaker: viola
lines.text: Et vous aussi; votre serviteur.

lines.speaker: sir andrew
lines.text: I hope, sir, you are; and I am yours.

lines.speaker: sir toby belch
lines.text: Will you encounter the house? my niece is desirous you should enter, if your trade be to her.

lines.speaker: viola
lines.text: I am bound to your niece, sir; I mean, she is the list of my voyage.

lines.speaker: sir toby belch
lines.text: Taste your legs, sir; put them to motion.

lines.speaker: viola
lines.text: My legs do better understand me, sir, than I understand what you mean by bidding me taste my legs.

lines.speaker: sir toby belch
lines.text: I mean, to go, sir, to enter.

lines.speaker: viola
lines.text: I will answer you with gait and entrance. But we are prevented. Most excellent accomplished lady, the heavens rain odours on you!
Enter OLIVIA and MARIA

lines.speaker: sir andrew
lines.text: That youth's a rare courtier: 'Rain odours;' well.

lines.speaker: viola
lines.text: My matter hath no voice, to your own most pregnant and vouchsafed ear.

lines.speaker: sir andrew
lines.text: 'Odours,' 'pregnant' and 'vouchsafed:' I'll get 'em all three all ready.

lines.speaker: olivia
lines.text: Let the garden door be shut, and leave me to my hearing. Give me your hand, sir.
Exeunt SIR TOBY BELCH, SIR ANDREW, and MARIA

lines.speaker: viola
lines.text: My duty, madam, and most humble service.

lines.speaker: olivia
lines.text: What is your name?

lines.speaker: viola
lines.text: Cesario is your servant's name, fair princess.

lines.speaker: olivia
lines.text: My servant, sir! 'Twas never merry world Since lowly feigning was call'd compliment: You're servant to the Count Orsino, youth.

lines.speaker: viola
lines.text: And he is yours, and his must needs be yours: Your servant's servant is your servant, madam.

lines.speaker: olivia
lines.text: For him, I think not on him: for his thoughts, Would they were blanks, rather than fill'd with me!

lines.speaker: viola
lines.text: Madam, I come to whet your gentle thoughts On his behalf.

lines.speaker: olivia
lines.text: O, by your leave, I pray you, I bade you never speak again of him: But, would you undertake another suit, I had rather hear you to solicit that Than music from the spheres.

lines.speaker: viola
lines.text: Dear lady,--

lines.speaker: olivia
lines.text: Give me leave, beseech you. I did send, After the last enchantment you did here, A ring in chase of you: so did I abuse Myself, my servant and, I fear me, you: Under your hard construction must I sit, To force that on you, in a shameful cunning, Which you knew none of yours: what might you think? Have you not set mine honour at the stake And baited it with all the unmuzzled thoughts That tyrannous heart can think? To one of your receiving Enough is shown: a cypress, not a bosom, Hideth my heart. So, let me hear you speak.

lines.speaker: viola
lines.text: I pity you.

lines.speaker: olivia
lines.text: That's a degree to love.

lines.speaker: viola
lines.text: No, not a grize; for 'tis a vulgar proof, That very oft we pity enemies.

lines.speaker: olivia
lines.text: Why, then, methinks 'tis time to smile again. O, world, how apt the poor are to be proud! If one should be a prey, how much the better To fall before the lion than the wolf! The clock upbraids me with the waste of time. Be not afraid, good youth, I will not have you: And yet, when wit and youth is come to harvest, Your were is alike to reap a proper man: There lies your way, due west.
Clock strikes

lines.speaker: viola
lines.text: Then westward-ho! Grace and good disposition Attend your ladyship! You'll nothing, madam, to my lord by me?

lines.speaker: olivia
lines.text: Stay: I prithee, tell me what thou thinkest of me.

lines.speaker: viola
lines.text: That you do think you are not what you are.

lines.speaker: olivia
lines.text: If I think so, I think the same of you.

lines.speaker: viola
lines.text: Then think you right: I am not what I am.

lines.speaker: olivia
lines.text: I would you were as I would have you be!

lines.speaker: viola
lines.text: Would it be better, madam, than I am? I wish it might, for now I am your fool.

lines.speaker: olivia
lines.text: O, what a deal of scorn looks beautiful In the contempt and anger of his lip! A murderous guilt shows not itself more soon Than love that would seem hid: love's night is noon. Cesario, by the roses of the spring, By maidhood, honour, truth and every thing, I love thee so, that, maugre all thy pride, Nor wit nor reason can my passion hide. Do not extort thy reasons from this clause, For that I woo, thou therefore hast no cause, But rather reason thus with reason fetter, Love sought is good, but given unsought better.

lines.speaker: viola
lines.text: By innocence I swear, and by my youth I have one heart, one bosom and one truth, And that no woman has; nor never none Shall mistress be of it, save I alone. And so adieu, good madam: never more Will I my master's tears to you deplore.

lines.speaker: olivia
lines.text: Yet come again; for thou perhaps mayst move That heart, which now abhors, to like his love.
Exeunt
